title: discover-places-keeping-vegan-food-scene-thriving
story: Tchai-OvnaHidden down a wee cobbled lane in the heart of Glasgowrsquos West End, on entering Tchai-Ovna you would be forgiven for thinking you are stepping into a Himalayan tea room or a Turkish bazar.Tchai-Ovna was founded in  by a group of Glasgow University students tired of the prevalent alcohol culture. When they first discovered the location, an old th C stables, it was badly in need of some t.l.c. but its magical, Bohemian, offbeat atmosphere was perfect. Too young to get business funding, with help from friends and the community they invested their student loans and refurbished the premises, keeping as many original features as possible: cobbled floors, horsersquos tethers etc. The vegetarian speciality tea house they created was only supposed to last a year, but almost twenty years on it is now a firmly established Glasgow institution."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Tchai-Ovna","description": "Tchai-Ovna","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media dSMDgrx poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests dSMDgrx.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Today the menu represents a broad swathe of cultures including Mexican, Arabic and Indian. It is produced by award winning vegetarian specialists the chipotle chilli won an award for one of the best chillis in the West End, and it is completely vegan. The vegan curry, produced by Balbirs Restaurants celebrated Punjabi chefs is hearty, tasty and authentic. Whilst you are enjoying your meal you can partake in one of around  speciality teas, all Tchai-Ovna own brand, and many of them blended in house and to order. They also retail many of the teas in the shop and online as well as wholesale across Scotland.Many know Tchai-Ovna as a much loved community hub, where people of all ages and backgrounds meet to socialise, play board games and listen to local, and international, live music acts and performances. It is welcoming, informal and unpretentious. Perhaps it is for this reason that even well-known celebs have become patrons. Belle and Sebastienrsquos album art for Dear Catastrophe Waitress was shot here, members of Franz Ferdinand stop by when they are not on tour, and Scarlett Johansson likes it so much she has been twice.Whatever your reason, be sure to stop by for a cuppa when you are in Glasgow.www.tchaiovna Otago LaneGlasgowG PBOpen am-pm every day----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Hanoi Bike ShopVietnamese food was vegan friendly before vegans were vegan. The streets of Hanoi are filled with vegetables and fresh produce that many of us here in Scotland have never heard of, let alone tasted. Plant-based food is everywhere in Vietnam and at the Hanoi Bike Shop they continue this tradition without ever sacricing taste or flavour.The little restaurant is situation just off Byres Road in the West End. The twinkly lights, Vietnamese flags and vintage bikes will draw you down the lane but once you get through the door donrsquot be put by the smell, they swear itrsquos not lsquowet dogrsquo or lsquohamster cagesrsquo as some TripAdvisor reviews would have you think. Fish sauce is a staple in Vietnamese cuisine and does leave a lasting impression on the senses. Although they use Tamariin all of their vegan dishes the fresh pho broths are always on the boil and help to give Hanoi its distinctive odour.Hanoi Bike Shop chefs have created a vegan menu influenced by seasonal availability of local produce as well as the salty, sweet, sour and spicy balance of Vietnamese cuisine.The star of course, is their organic handmade tofu, which is carefully, simmered, strained and pressed daily in house.Hanoirsquos vegan menu consists of over twenty freshly prepared dishes ranging from Kimchi Spring Rolls and Daikon and Soya Bean Cakes to Chilli Glazed Sesame Rice Cakes and Curried Banana.They implore all customers to adopt their dining motto lsquosharing is caringrsquo and go for the lsquoFeed Mersquo option. The passionate staff will listen to your likes and dislikes and design a bespoke banquet around you. Then you just sit back, relax and let the banquet begin.www.hanoibikeshopInstagram www.instagram hanoibikeshop Facebook www.facebook TheHanoiBikeShop booking.resdiary widget Standard HanoiBikeShop  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------OM Sweet OMOM Sweet OM is a vibrant haven, tucked behind Central Station in Oswald St, in the centre of Glasgow, committed to the art of sustainable happiness and conscious living. The charity is set up to promote well-being which will empower you to experience a higher taste in le thus satisfying your physical, emotional and spiritual needs.Inspired by the ancient Bhakti tradition of Vedic culture they integrate and unite the ious yoga systems to form a lestyle to benefit yourself, those around you, the planet and all of its ied inhabitants.OM Sweet OM practice Ahimsa, the principle of non-violence, in their vegan dishes and lestyle to increase compassion for all living beings and reduce harm to our environment. A plant-based diet is crucial for their inidual wellbeing and that of the planet itself.Most of their events feature vegan meals and all of the meals served in OM Sweet OM are lovingly prepared by the cooks at Krishna Eco Farm www.facebook krishnaecofarm  to a very high standard, often using produce fresh from the gardens. They have a thriving programme providing free vegan food on the streets of Glasgow via the project Food for Scotland www.facebook foodscotland. This is aimed at homeless people and also promote plant-based diets."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "OM Sweet OM","description": "OM Sweet OM","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media PfqkSp poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests PfqkSp.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Just as the body needs nourishment by vegan superfood, they also offer yoga classes to maintain a good flow of healthy energy. They have classes to suit all levels of practitioners and even entry level by donation to encourage newcomers to try. Award-winning yoga teacher, Daniel Gronan, has several lively classes featuring vinyasa yoga and mantra movement.For those wanting to e deeper into philosophy, there are classes available to discover and discuss timeless yoga wisdom of India. Many psychologists and neurologists are realising the benefits of mantra sound vibrations on our well-being.In conjunction with Krishna Eco Farm, retreats are available to immerse oneself in yoga, mindfulness and mantra meditation in the beautul countryside of Lesmahagow, with wonderful vegan meals.OM Sweet OM, Food for Scotland and Krishna Eco Farm are all projects of ISKCON Scotland, charity number SC.www.omsweetomwww.facebook omsweetomglasgowwww.instagram omsweetom.glasgow----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Kalpna Indian Vegan and Vegetarian RestaurantOpen since , Kalpna Indian Vegan and Vegetarian Restaurant stands as one of Edinburghrsquos most established Institution. title: If Labour win  it  39 ll be less like Venezuela than Britain circa 1974
story: Jeremy Corbyn was also talking tough this week. He identied some of the capitalist criminals Labour is coming for, including Sir Jim Ratclfe of Ineos. Though itrsquos not clear under what law the polluting plutocrats could be prosecuted.So, is this class war in the UK  Are we on the road to Venezuela  Whatever the polls say, a Labour victory this Christmas is quite possible with Nigel Faragersquos Brexit Party now splitting the Tory vote. There is a powerful mood for change in Britain. But what would a Labour government actually look like We have never had such an avowedly radical Prime Minister ndash not even in , when Labour was led by a small ldquoc conservative, Clement Attlee. However, Labour reality would be rather dferent from the rhetoric. Burrow into Labourrsquos policies, and what emerges looks more like reheated social democracy, circa, than a Bolshevik revolution.For a start, we can largely ignore the issue that ided the party so bitterly in recent times: nuclear weapons. Jeremy Corbyn may be a lelong member of CND, but Labour is no longer a unilateralist party. Its  manesto committed a Labour government to renewing Trident almost indefinitely.But Corbyn will still enter Number  with a raft of left-wing policies, from seizing corporate assets to abolishing private schools as well as taxing the rich until the pips squeak. However, many of the headline policies will never make it to first reading, let alone the statute book.Abolishing schools like Eton would involve y court action, not least from faith schools and the home school movement, who might also be affected. Labour is more likely to confine its assault on educational privilege to axeing tax reliefs worth about pound. billionSimilarly, seizing % of the shares of companies with more than  employees would be fiercely resisted in the courts by shareholders. They have deep pockets. I suspect Labour would confine itself to increasing corporate taxes, ending zero-hours contracts and restoring trades union rights ndash all of which are eminently doable.Indeed, looking behind the radical rhetoric, much of Labourrsquos policy agenda is surprisingly modest, viewed from Scotland. Measures like free personal care, abolishing university tuition fees, childcare for three and four-year-olds, scrapping the right to buy, lting the benefits cap and the bedroom tax ndash these are all achievable.Indeed, the Scottish Parliament has already achieved them, bar the welfare cap. Nicola Sturgeon will no doubt remind the Labour leader of this repeatedly in coming weeks.Nationalisation is a policy that used to be seen as ldquoloony left but is no longer. Taking rail into public ownership shouldnrsquot be too much of a problem, since Network Rail, which owns the track and signalling, is already in public hands. The service franchises could be replaced as they come up for renewal, without needing to hand billions in compensation to Virgin and the rest.Waterand energy would pose greater problems, not least because most of our energy companies are foreign-owned ndash often, ironically, by state-owned bodies. But with a good wind it should be possible for Labour to find a way. Public attitudes to public ownership of utilities have changed out of all recognition since the s.Similarly, there is broad public support for Labourrsquos Green New Deal. A majority of voters agrees there is a climate emergency. Though they may not agree with the measures needed to tackle it.Labour is not going the full Extinction Rebellion route of making Britain zero carbon by . But its own policy, passed at conference, is still pretty radical. It commits a Labour government to making Britain zero carbon by . Thatrsquos only five years longer.We are talking about the most radical change to our lestyles since the industrial revolution. Labourrsquos policy would mean decarbonising transport, home heating and agriculture in a decade. Millions of cars would have to be scrapped along with millions of home boilers. Air travel would all but cease.Labour promises a huge investment in renewable industries to compensate, but that is unlikely to replace the jobs lost in the car industry, oil and gas, road haulage and retail.So expect the Green New Deal to become somewhat lighter green in government. There is likely to be a rt between the Thunberg-supporting ldquode-growthers and Labour MPs, who traditionally see economic growth as the best way to address poverty and inequality.However, Britain already has a rather good record on eliminating greenhouse emissions, and this will continue, albeit with the  target reduced to % net zero.In sum, Labour offers a practical social democratic programme which could be very attractive to voters, especially younger ones. However there is one very big problem: Brexit.Labour is committed to negotiating a new Withdrawal Deal to replace Boris Johnsonrsquosand to putting this to another Brexit referendum. This will consume a vast amount of political capital and will surely dominate the first year of a Labour government.Corbyn wants to reintroduce the customs union and Brussels would probably agree to that. But Labour also wants close regulatory alignment with the European Single Market, which the EU  would probably reject. If Britain wants to be in the single market, it will have to join the single market, probably via the European Economic Area, along with Norway.Labour could go along with that in the end, since it wants friction-free access to the EU markets. Single market membership would solve the Irish border problem, for sure.But it would also mean Britain continuing to contribute to the EU Budget, while having no say over decisions taken by Brussels. Customs union membership requires oversight by the European Court of Justice, which will displease many.But that wouldnrsquot be the main problem. If Labour got this wonderful deal, including workersrsquo rights and environmental standards, and got it through Parliament , would it really then campaign against it in the confirmatory referendum Interviewers have largely stopped asking this question, because they never get an answer, but Europe remains a huge question mark hanging over Labourrsquos government agenda.Labour is still a Brexit party, though you wouldnrsquot know it to listen to most MPs. Many figures in the party are closet Brexiteers, like Jeremy Corbyn himself. Others are openly pro-Brexit, like the party chairman Ian Lavery and the MPs who voted for Boris Johnsonrsquos deal.Equally dedicated Remainers ndash mostly Blairites and supporters of the deputy leader Tom Watson ndash would fight back, insisting that Labour effectively promised to back Remain in the General Election. Brexit wrangling could delay the confirmatory referendum and ide the party, just as it split the Tories.Corbynrsquos enemies will ignite further ision by condemning him as anti-Semitic. It will take immense powers of leadership to prevent a Labour government being halted in its radical tracks by Brexit.The question for voters is: does Jeremy Corbyn possess it

title: 70-000-trees-take-root-scottish-schools
story: East Lothian nursery Alba Trees, is providing a range of packs to suit dferent needs on behalf of the Woodland Trust on a first come first served basis to any groups that will use them to help green public spaces.Nearly , schools and other groups will receive , saplings this month, thanks to the initiative which is funded by Sainsburyrsquos, Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery, Yorkshire Tea and Selfridges.In Scotland alone, , trees are being sent out to  dferent organisations.Woodland Trust Scotland Director Carol Evans said tree planting had never been higher on the social and political agenda, amid increasing public awareness that we are in a climate crisis.ldquoPeople are waking up to the message that trees are a big part of the solution to tackling climate change, she said.ldquoWe need more of them so it is fantastic that we are able to provide these free trees for schools and communities across the country.Woodland Trustsrsquos Big Climate Fightback aims to get more than a million people to pledge to plant a tree on the run up to a mass day of planting across the UK on November .ldquoReducing our carbon emissions will never be enough. Itrsquos vital we grow a UK-wide patchwork of trees and woods - not just by planting, but also through natural regeneration, the campaign says. ldquoThe woods, hedges and green spaces we create buffer existing habitats, tackle climate change and reverse wildle decline ndash all at the same time.Groups are also being invited to apply for a free tree pack as part of the next round of deliveries which will be sent out in March , with organisations that apply getting added to a list of trustees.As well as schools ndash which must plant the trees on the school grounds ndash community groups are eligible so long as the trees are planted on land which is publicly accessible.Applicants must provide a grid reference for the land they wish to plant on, and also secure the permission of the landownernecessary or demonstrate local community support.The packs will be allocated until they run out, but those applying will need sufficient space: the smallest packs are for restricted urban spaces but still include  trees, while larger packs contain up to  trees ndash enough to fill a football pitch.Depending on a grouprsquos requirements, would-be planters can choose from eight dferent categories of pack.The Hedge pack contains  trees, a mix of dog rose, hawthorn, hazel, crab apple and dogwood, enough for eight metres of lsquoeasy to managersquo hedging. Copse contains enough saplings to plant a ldquosmall tranquil copse that is an oasis for birds, including silver birch, rowan and wild cherry.Wild Harvest includes species such as hazel, blackthorn, crab apple and elder, which will produce an array of fruits and nuts suitable for preserving as jams, jellies, wines or cordials, while the lsquoYear Round Colourrsquo pack promises beautul blossoms, bright berries stunning shades in the autumn and includes wild cherry and dogwood.The industrious can order a Working Wood pack which will provide logs for fuel in - years or materials for crafts such as carving and willow weaving. This pack includes common oak, field maple and grey willow. Groups seeking something less domesticated, or those with exposed sites or boggy ground can request a Wild Wood pack, which includes hawthorn, holly, downy birch and goat willow.The popular Wildle pack aims to provide both food and shelter for beasts large and small, and includes a mix of traditional species such as hawthorn, blackthorn and silver birch. Finally the Urban Trees pack - which is designed for residential areas with limited communal space - offers a mixture of  saplings from three species, crab apple, rowan and hazel , all well-equipped to thrive in urban settings.All the trees are sourced in the UK and grown under the Trustrsquos quality assurance scheme guaranteeing the provenance of native trees.Launched last year the UKSGguarantees that trees awarded the badge are raised from seeds sourced only from the UK and grown in the UK for their entire lespan.The aim is to reduce the risk of importing pests and diseases with planting stock grown outside the UK. Groups wishing to apply can visit www.woodlandtrust.org.uk freetrees.Established in , the Woodland Trust aims to protect and restore ancient woodland while planting native trees to create ldquoresilient woods benefitting both people and wildle.

title: no-nonsense-new-speaker-not-afraid-ruffle-snp-feathers
story: The -year-old Labour politician, who was knighted in  for parliamentary and political services, also clashed with former Scottish First Minister Alex Salmond during a Brexit debate in February .Mr Salmond accused the Deputy Speaker of cutting off SNP MP Joanna Cherry while she was speaking and the row escalated as Mr Hoyle shouted that Mr Salmond ldquoshould know better and ordered him to ldquosit down. Tempers were rising after seven hours of debate as the Brexit Bill that would trigger Article  reached committee stage in the Commons.:Sir Lindsay Hoyle elected new speaker of the House of CommonsThe row occurred after the Mr Salmond raised a point of order saying: "It is quite clear that the honourable member had not resumed her seat, Sir. Being in the chair accords you many privileges but you cannot reinterpret the wishes of an honourable member who is on her feet."Mr Hoyle responded: "As the chair I have the right to make decisions on this House. What I would say is quite rightly when I wanted to bring her in [Joanna Cherry MP], which I did ... I certainly dont expect advantages to be taken of the chair on the agreements that I make."Referring to the Brexit Bill, he said: "It is a very serious matter, it is so serious that I want to hear what the minister has to say."Mr Hoyle has been widely complimented for his approach to handling Budget debates, which has been part of his job as chairman of Ways and Means.:Sir Lindsay Hoyle elected new speaker of the House of CommonsHe taught his pet parrot Boris to shout ldquoorder order! and named his tortoise Maggie, after the late Tory Prime Minister because she had a hard shell and was "not for turning".The Lancashire-born businessman was one of just three Labour MPs who did not declare their voting intention in the  EU referendum. His Lancashire district backed Brexit by % to %.He vowed to "tame the bear pit" of a "toxic Parliament"elected to the role of Speaker, sayinghe would crack down on aggressive language.He went to private Lords College in Bolton and ran his own screen-printing firm before becoming an MP in .The seasonedpolitician was elected as Deputy Speaker of the House in a secret ballot on June .He was in the Speakerrsquos chair at the time of the Westminster Terror Attack of  March  - and the subsequent lockdown of the Houses of Parliament.After winning the final round of voting on Monday against Chris Bryant, Sir Lindsay was dragged to the chair by MPs, where he pledged to be a "neutral" Speaker.He also paid tribute to his daughter, Natalie, who died in , saying she would "always be missed".

title: footballs-really-coming-home-plans-restoration-original-hampden-site-unveiled-tennents
story: But now, the location of the worldrsquos first purpose-built international football ground is set to be properly recognised for the first time.Hampden Bowling Club is long suspected to be the site of Scotlandrsquos original national stadium - playing host to our - thrashing of England in .However, the rich history of the former stadium - which also played host to the pioneering Queenrsquos Park side of the late th century - has long been lost since the majority of the structure which stood on the site was dismantled in the rsquos to make way for a railway line.:Club mural marks the lsquolostrsquo home of footballNow, brewer Tennentrsquos has unveiled new plans to ldquorestore, repair and celebrate the legacy of Scotlandrsquos first footballing home thanks to a five-figure investment which will see parts of the bowling club pavillion that retain the features of the original faithfully revived.James Hughes, Tennentrsquos brand manager, said: ldquoWersquore in no doubt about the signicance Hampden Bowling Club has in world football. Tennentrsquos is as synonymous with the game in Scotland as the Hampden Roar and the half-time pie.ldquoWersquore thrilled to continue our long and proud association with Scottish football and to be able to play our part in preserving the most important site in the history of the worldrsquos favourite sport - just a couple of miles from the site of one of Scotlandrsquos oldest breweries.He added: ldquoHugh Tennent was a man who loved to engage with his cityrsquos culture in the late s, and wersquore confident Hugh would have been at the first Hampden Park cheering on Scotland in their triumphs in the early days of Tennentrsquos Lager.Under the proposals, the roof, windows and electrics within the pavilion will be completely repaired, with the outside grounds - which contain a mural celebrating Scotlandrsquos win over the Auld Enemy and a tribute to Andrew Watson, believed to be the first black player in association football - also improved.A lsquoTennentrsquos Redrsquo plaque has been unveiled at the site - thought to have given birth to the version of the game as it is now known the world over.The Hampden Collection - a group committed to promoting the legacy of the Three Hampdens - claim the venue is home to the ldquomodern lsquopass and moversquo style of football, believed to have been invented by Scottish clans more than  years ago.It was later passed down through the generations in northern Scotland, with the Highlandersrsquo influence shaping the game when many of them moved south to Glasgow and formed Queenrsquos Park in .The attractive style of play was later adopted around the world, influencing the great Brazil side of , the Dutch interpretation of lsquoTotal Footballrsquo and Barcelonarsquos lsquotiki-takarsquo of the modern era.The stadium hosted the first ever Scottish Cup final, a - win for The Spiders against Clydesdale in  as well as several early Scotland international matches.The second Hampden Park opened in  and later became known as lsquoCathkin Park,rsquo while the current site came into use in October .Scottish Football Museum creator Ged OrsquoBrien said: ldquoThe line in the song lsquofootballrsquos coming homersquo is simply not correct.: The Five Greatest Scotland Football TeamsldquoThe true home of the passing and running game is what we know now as Hampden Bowling Club. This style of contest was so popular and successful that it was exported from Scotland all over the world.He added: ldquoIt became the way the game was played around the world, and we have evidence to the fact that it was officially established here in Glasgow.The Hampden Collection have promoted the refurbishment of the site on social media, using the hashtag #RestorestHampden.Graeme Brown, Co-Founder of the Hampden Collection, said: ldquoAs wersquove seen at all three Hampden venues over the years, great teams can do great things.""Wersquore delighted to have teamed up with Tennentrsquos to kick-off our drive to #RestorestHampden and ensure it becomes an essential part of Scottish History for future generations to enjoy.

title: vintage-couple-take-diners-back-time-1940s-tearoom
story: The walls are decorated with posters of rock-and-roll stars Elvis Presley and Gene Vincent. A radio on an art deco mantle plays oldies from the s.Samantha, whose pin-curled hair is fastened with a pink flower to match her ankle- skirt, bakes every kind of homemade goodie from Victorian sponge cakes to fresh scones.Visitors wonrsquot find internet for their electronics, but they will regularly see patrons, from elderly couples enjoying tea to busy students working on assignments. That is because the dated tile floors and mismatched vintage furniture isnrsquot inside the Newellrsquos home ndash itrsquos their family business nestled cozily in an upstairs apartment on Ashton Lane.ldquoI want this to take them back to grandmarsquos house, Samantha said. ldquoWhen serving people things, I donrsquot do dainty. I give what I would like to have myself, soI serve a piece of cakehellip itrsquos going to be a whole piece of cake.:Cake critic -The Cup and Saucer Vintage Tearoom, GlasgowThe Cup and Saucer Vintage Tea Room was born out of the couplersquos love for all things vintage. When Tony was  years old, he came across a Gene Vincent record, and since then began styling himself as a teddy boy, complete with a greased quf hairdo and tight jeans. ldquoBack then when I used to wear my leather jacket old ladies would walk across the road to avoid me, Tony said. ldquoBut in Glasgow no-one bats an eye. Most people react with a smile.While it took several years for the tearoom to become the local staple it is today, the Newellrsquos partnership was love at first sight. The couple met on a school bus in  when they were  years old and married five years later. Samantha said she was initially into the hard rock of the s and s, but Tonyrsquos passion for vintage slowly changed her aestheticism. She began by making her own circle skirts, and now exclusively wears vintage clothing like her husband.Samantha said dressing in vintage makes her feel classy and smart like she is part of an era where people cared about style and how they were presented. Sometimes patrons think the couplersquos dress is a unorm, and that they go home and put on lsquonormal clothesrsquo at the end of the day.ldquoItrsquos like a kind of unorm but itrsquos not, Samantha said. ldquoItrsquos just us. Itrsquos not for the tearoom. Itrsquos us every day.The business began when Samantha wanted to share her baking with the community. She initially ran it alone with Tony and their two children helping on weekends. When Tony concluded his service in the Royal Navy after a -year career, he came to work full-time.Most of the furniture comes from their home, as they try to live as authentic a vintage lestyle they can. Any electronics they do use such as a microwave and CD player are hidden in cabinets. Some items are also donated by regulars to the cafeacute, such as a cabinet from a grandmotherrsquos garage that now holds old saucers. Samantha says when someone donates cups or plates, she tries her best to serve them with it when they come to eat.The Cup and Saucer is coming upon its eight-year anniversary, and the couple says its mission still stands: to give people living in the busy city of Glasgow a place to relax. Their advertisement is exclusively by word-of-mouth, and they are proud that the tearoom is not on the main street.Tony said they donrsquot want to put more tables in so people are sat on top of each other because it would ruin the homey feel. However, even with no advertisement there is still a queue to get in on weekends, which he said is a testament to his wersquos baking.Leslie Watson, a woman in her s ing to school to study climate justice, has become a regular patron to the Cup and Saucer because of its relaxing atmosphere.ldquoI feel like Irsquom at my grandparentsrsquo house like everythingrsquos okay in the world, Watson said.The couple ndash who call each other their best friend ndash have no plans to change the shop anytime soon. In their spare time Samantha said she has dreams to be on the British Bake Off, and Tony DJs local rockabilly shows as DJ Sailor Tony.Both say that they arenrsquot trying to be pretentious by their vintage lestyle, but that they want to create a little home in Glasgow for those who need it.ldquoWe hope that they leave full of the happy memories that wersquove taken them back to, Samantha said.

title: neil-mackay-question-time-comes-scotland-week---must-stop-destruction-trust
story: During the last edition of the political  show the broadcaster allowed lies and disinformation to go out over the airwaves uncorrected, infecting public discourse.An audience member told the  that the Vote Leave campaign had broken electoral law, and said Dominic Cummings, the Prime Ministerrsquos special adviser, had refused to come before parliament.Presenter Fiona Bruce told the young woman: ldquoIrsquom not entirely sure yoursquore right about that. Bruce also appeared to confuse Vote Leave with the Leave.EU campaign.The young woman defended her position, but was told by Bruce ldquono criminal charges were brought.The right-wing journalist Isabel Oakeshott, who was a list, then jumped in to say: ldquoThe vast majority of allegations about both Leave campaigns were found to be completely untrue. This was propaganda.The audience member was correct, however ndash Vote Leave broke the law. Yet, any viewer would have left the programme believing the opposite.This is a critical failure by the BBC. The national broadcaster is meant to provide unbiased, accurate reporting. It did the opposite on Question Time.This General Election is one that will be fought on lies, deceit and manipulation. Thatrsquos why facts, truth and trust are the most vital issues for the electorate.Herersquos a reminder of what the BBC should have told viewers. Vote Leave was fined pound, for breaking electoral law over spending limits. In March this year, it dropped its appeal against the fine. Vote Leave was fronted by Boris Johnson. Cummings was campaign director.The Electoral Commission said: ldquoSerious offences such as these undermine public confidence in our system and it is vital, therefore, that they are properly investigated and sanctioned.A day after Question Time aired, it emerged evidence relating to overspending, which could lead to criminal charges against Vote Leave, had been passed by police to the Crown Prosecution Service.The House of Commonrsquos Privileges Committee said Cummings had committed a contempt of Parliament by not appearing to give evidence when ordered as part of an inquiry into fake news.The fact that Question Time acted as a distributor for lies on an issue which is right at the very heart of Brexit and the forthcoming General Election makes the broadcasterrsquos failings ever more egregious.I donrsquot see bias at every turn with the BBC. Irsquove mostly great respect for the broadcaster in terms of its journalism and also its cultural output. When I see it attacked by both right and left, Leave and Remain, unionists and Yes voters, Irsquom pretty confident itrsquos doing its job and holding all sides of the political spectrum to account. Demonstrations against the BBC and hate campaigns against reporters run contrary to every democratic bone in my body. I see them as the first steps on the path to authoritarianism and populism.However, the BBC as a whole suffers from a fatal weakness: its automatic default position is to defend the status quo. When authority speaks, it accepts and parrots, it doesnrsquot question and interrogate. Radical voices are subjected to withering scrutiny, reactionary voices are treated with respect and dignity. This skews debate and immediately sets up imbalance.We saw the same problem here in Scotland during the independence referendum. The knee-jerk position was to subject the Yes campaign to forensic investigation, while broadly accepting most of what the No campaign said on face value. Both sides should have been put under the same pressure.There are also flaws built in to Question Time, which are now becoming damaging to democracy. The show isnrsquot about debate and getting to the facts, itrsquos TV clickbait. Itrsquos about screaming matches and outrage. Itrsquos a shock-jock show dressed up in the boring clothes of a politician.:Election : Jeremy Corbyn accuses Boris Johnson over NHSHere in Scotland, wersquore used to the games Question Time plays. Eyebrows were raised when a former UKIP member called Billy Mitchell appeared on the show for the fourth time in Scotland. Mitchell claimed he was invited by the showrsquos producer.The damage done to the BBCrsquos reputation by last weekrsquos show was immediate and deep. Shahmir Sanni, the whistleblower who exposed Vote Leave spending, said: ldquoOh my f**king God. Theyrsquore not even trying to hide it anymore! This audience member recalls Vote Leave breaking electoral law and Fiona Bruce literally lies saying lsquothey were cleared of those accusationsrsquo.Wersquoll be in serious trouble during this electionthe BBC shatters trust in itself. The public needs the BBC more than ever as an arbiter of whatrsquos true and whatrsquos lies in this era of mass manipulation and propaganda.Johnsonrsquos government is currently sitting on a report into Russian interference in British democracy. Dominic Grieve, the former Tory attorney-general, has called for its publication before the election.:Glasgow set to host BBC Question Time in run up to general electionThe Labour Party has began to question Dominic Cummings links to Russia. Emily Thornberry, shadow foreign secretary, wrote to the government asking about his connections to Russia and the level of security vetting to which hersquos been subjected in Downing Street.Amid all this, wersquove the truly grave threat Facebook poses to democracy. The social media giant will allow British politicians to run  ads on the site. To make the matter even more disgusting, the policy is being championed by Facebook executive Nick Clegg, the former LibDem deputy Prime Minister, who once spoke out about ldquothe colossal scale of the lies spread by the Leave campaign.Johnson and his new Tory radicals are also shameless in their deceit. Outgoing European Commission President, Jean-Claude Junker, said yesterday of the EU referendum: ldquoSo many lies were told, including by current prime minister, Boris Johnson, that there needed to be a voice to counter them.Chief among the voices countering lies should be the BBC. It shouldnrsquot be amplying hoods. Perhaps, one starting solution would be to change the format of Question Time by adding in a fact-checker service. While the  debate, a team of journalists could sit behind them double-checkingwhat they are saying is true. If they lie, fact-checkers should interrupt the show and tell viewers the truth. That would be a real service to democracy, and to the public, when we need it most.Neil Mackay is Scotlandrsquos Columnist of the Year

title: self-sample-home-urine-test-increase-cervical-screening-uptake
story: Researchers have developed a way to identy pre-cancer lesions by analysing urine and vaginal samples that could be collected by women in the comfort of their own home.The ldquoself-sampling test proved popular with women taking part in the study, meaning it is likely to improve participation in cervical screening programmesmade widely available, they believe.Dr Belinda Nedjai, director of the Molecular Epidemiology Lab at Queen Mary University of London, said: ldquoThe initial use of self-sampling is likely to be for women who do not attend clinic after a screening invitation and countries without a cervical cancer screening programme.ldquoIn the longer term, self-sampling could become the standard method for all screening tests.ldquoThe study indicated that women much preferred doing a test at home than attending a doctorrsquos surgery.:Analysis: NHS too important not to be a political footballShe added: ldquoWe expect the self-sampling test to improve acceptance rates for cervical cancer screening, as well as reducing costs to health services and improving the performance of screening programmes.Dr Nedjai told the  NCRI Cancer Conference in Glasgow that the study was the largest to test for the S methylation classier, a chemical change to one of the four DNA base letters that make up the human genetic code.The test looks at the methylation of four HPVtypes most strongly associated with cancer and a human gene to calculate a risk score.It is estimated thateveryone attended screening regularly, % of cervical cancer cases could be prevented. If youre nervous, breathing exercises can help and nurses are trained to make you as comfortable as possible. #CervicalScreeningSavesLives #SexualHealthAwarenessWeek pic cVWwfXmmdash Public Health EnglandSeptember , In earlier research, they found that the test, when performed on cervical samples taken by healthcare professionals, was % accurate at detecting invasive cervical cancer, and % accurate at detecting pre-cancer in women who had an HPV positive test.In the new study,  women with abnormal smear tests or positive HPV results were asked to provide vaginal samples collected themselves using swabs.The researchers extracted and analysed the DNA in the lab and generated S scores.In urine samples, the S test was better at correctly identying women who did have pre-cancer lesions than existing HPV tests.:Chief of Royal College of Surgeons Edinburgh Alison Rooney forced out in no confidence voteThe S test correctly identied high-risk pre-cancerous cells in % of samples compared with % with an HPV- or  test.They believe it could be used in two ways ndash as a secondary test on HPV-positive women, or as a standalone test, where it correctly identied % of samples that were pre-cancerous.Dr Nedjai added: ldquoWe are currently working on new markers to try to improve the accuracy of the classier even further, but these findings represent an advance in cervical cancer screening, especially for women who do not attend the clinic, such as older women, or women who find the smear test too painful or who do not have access to a screening programme in their country. We think itrsquos promising.

story: His apology came after an LBC appearance on Monday, during which the Commons leader had discussed London Fire Brigadersquoslsquostay-putrsquo policy and said: ldquoIf you just ignore what yoursquore told and leave you are so much safer.ldquoI thinkeither of us were in a fire, whatever the fire brigade said, we would leave the burning building.ldquoIt just seems the common sense thing to do, and it is such a tragedy that that didnrsquot happen."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Jacob Rees-Mogg apologises for Grenfell common sense comment","description": "Jacob Rees-Mogg apologises for Grenfell common sense comment","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media fKXzcJ poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests fKXzcJ.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": But after calls to apologise, Mr Rees-Mogg said on Tuesday: ldquoWhat I meant to say is that I would have also listened to the fire brigadersquos advice to stay and wait at the time.ldquoHowever, with what we know now and with hindsight I wouldnrsquot and I donrsquot think anyone  would.ldquoI would hate to upset the people of GrenfellI was unclear in my comments.The originalcomments were called ldquocrass and ldquoinsensitive by Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, and Grenfell United said his words were ldquoextremely painful and insulting to bereaved families.The Leader of the House of Commons suggesting that the  people who lost their lives at Grenfell lacked common sense is beyond disrespectful. It is extremely painful and insulting to bereaved families.mdash Grenfell UnitedNovember , On Tuesday, thehead of the London Fire Brigadesaid that ldquoknowing what we know now, the service would respond dferently to a Grenfell-like fire.LFB Commissioner, Dany Cotton, was answering questions at the London Assembly about the inquiry report into the  blaze that killed  people.She told the fire, resilience and emergency planning committee: ldquoClearly, knowing what we know now about Grenfell Tower and similar buildings with ACM cladding, our response would be very dferent.When asked how the service had changed its approaches, she added: ldquoNot only have we increased our attendancewe receive a call to a high rise fire, we increase the number of fire engines we send.What possesses someone to react to an entirely avoidable tragedy like Grenfell by saying the victims lacked common sense  People were terried, many died trying to escape. Jacob Rees Mogg must apologise for these crass and insensitive comments immediately.https:t.co QczWiyxkRmdash Jeremy CorbynNovember , ldquoIf there are multiple calls to the same building and the callers state the outside of the building is on fire we send an initial attendance of ten fire engines, plus officers, plus specialist appliances.Ms Cotton also expressed concern for the number of buildings covered in similar material to the Kensington tower.She told the committee: ldquoWe know that there are still several hundred buildings in London that are covered in ACM cladding [hellip] our concern is that action is not being taken quickly enough to remove that cladding which is a high risk.

title: brexit-could-mean-border-checks-england-scotland-wales
story: Issues such as chlorinated chicken and genetically-modiedcrops in post-Brexit trade negotiations could create wider dferences between the nationsrsquo food safety standards and require border checks between countries, University of Sussex academics have said.With the Scottish and Welsh Governments pledging to remain aligned to EU standards after Brexit, trade deals made by the UK Government ldquocould complicate and undermine trade in agricultural and food products, the report states.:Neil Mackay: Question Time comes to Scotland this week ndash it must stop the destruction of trust"@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Brexit:  days until Britain is scheduled to leave the EU","description": "Brexit:  days until Britain is scheduled to leave the EU","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media KdZxfJE poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests KdZxfJE.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Our new briefing paper is finally out! We look at Brexit food safety legislation on GMOs, pesticides, food additives and microbiological food safetyand its potential trade impacts: https:t.co RerBdHmdash Emily LydgateNovember , The university study, carried out for the UK Trade Policy Observatory, said dferent approaches to food standards would likely have a ldquosignicant and detrimental impact on the ability to strike trade deals and ldquoposes an increased risk of fragmentation within the UK.Proposed Brexit food safety rules would give UK ministers powers to make policy changes to food safety laws without primary legislation ndash avoiding the scrutiny of Parliament through the use of Statutory Instruments .:Mark Smith: The  Scottish seats that matter ndash and the critical group of voters that will decide who wins themSuch changes have the potential to ldquovastly increase devolution of food safety regulation, according to the report, creating the prospect of trade barriers between England and Scotland or Wales.Dr Emily Lydgate, a senior environmental law lecturer at the University of Sussex and one of the authors of the study, said: ldquoFood safety SIs are a potential flash-point for Scotland ndash which wants to maintain alignment with the EU ndash and Westminster, which promises to pursue a US trade deal that will alter UK food safety legislation.ldquoNegotiating a US trade deal that Scotland opposes is certainly not viable and could even fuel a push for Scottish independence.ldquoIf one or more devolved administrations refuses to realign its food safety regulations from those of the EU to comply with US standards after a US-UK free trade agreement, it will complicate the flows of agricultural and food products within the UK.ldquoThis raises the question of how the UK can avoid introducing internal UK regulatory controls and border checks to ensure that products comply with ergent jurisdictional requirements.The report also suggests EU safeguards on food standards will be weakened as soon as the UK leaves, with the Government planning to scrap the requirement for independent scientic assessments on the safety of pesticides and allowing minister to lower thresholds for labelling when genetically-modied crops are used.Professor Erik Millstone, emeritus professor in the Science Policy Research Unit at the University of Sussex, said: ldquoOur analysis suggests Brexit SIs will allow ministers to exercise considerable powers of discretion when authorising ingredients in pesticide products, amending GMO authorisations and thresholds for labelling, authorising food additives and approving substances for animal carcass washes.ldquoMinisters may issue guidance impacting substantive policy content or make new rules governing food safety by secondary legislation, without proper parliamentary scrutiny and using powers that exceed those vested by the EU in the European Commission.ldquoThose considerable powers could be a way to overcoming parliamentary resistance and public opposition to aspects of a UK-US trade deal.Recommending that devolved nations have ldquostrong oversight over UK external trade negotiations, the study also calls for primary legislation to be required where there could be major policy changes on food safety.

title: bake-offs-flora-shedden-my-generation-delusional-approach-food
story: If the Think Global, Eat Local mantra is being appropriated by mindful Millennials , then Flora Shedden is arguably a standard-bearer of the generations she spans. Originally coined some years ago by older campaigners wishing for a more sustainable, secure and resilient system of food production and distribution, the -year-old Scot is taking up the baton ndash albeit it on a tiny Perthshire footprint.Four years ago, at the age of , the Dunkeld-born student became the youngest-ever finalist in the long-running reality baking show The Great British Bake-Off [GBBO]. Watched by  million viewers worldwide, she was the runner-up in the  finale and instantly became a media darling. Evidently thrilled and reassured in equal measure to have such a young woman embrace ndash in her reassuring mid-Scots accent ndash the ancient culinary art of baking using centuries-old techniques, print and broadcast commissioning editors flocked to her oven door. Her first cookbook was published, and her online presence rose faster than the lightest souffle. Here was a new domestic goddess in whose delicate hands baking was safe. The world, it seemed, was her ice-cream oyster.Then she turned the tables. Eschewing the bright lights, she has settled instead for her own tiny craft bakery in a th century village in rural Perthshire where she quietly and happily puts in a -hour day. Itrsquos from this modest ndashinfinitely pretty ndash base that she hopes to influence our relationship with food for the better.Not that shersquos about to disappear completely: with its white-painted -year-old stone walls, original black range, front door draped with garlands of dried flowers, the setting for her glass-fronted display of fresh craft bakery items, Aran, is the last word in Instagrammability. Named after the Gaelic for bread, it is also the title of her second cookbook.ldquoYeah, it was a bit of a ballsy move, she agrees of her snap decision to buy the bakery in . ldquoItrsquos been wonderful. I call it my flour oasis. Wersquore perched on little white-painted stepping stools in a corner of the busy shop floor, trying not to get in the way of the constant stream of customers ndash a combination of locals and tourists ndash looking for her trademark homemade croissants, cakes, pastries and sourdough breads which have sustainability hard-baked into every bite.Shedden put her studies on hold ndash she was doing a history of art degree at St Andrews ndash to set up Aran with her friend Angus and her boyfriend of just five months at the time, James Irvine, who now manages the Birnam Arts Centre. The pair live together in the flat above the shop. A crowdfunding campaign raised pound, for refurbishment and grants from the SSE windfarm community fund, combined with a bank loan and proceeds from her first book Gatherings, made her long-held dream possible.ldquoIrsquod immediately become jealous when Angus told me he had a lsquobread shedrsquo, a place where he would create loaves upon loaves post-work and early in the morning, she says. ldquoHis magic little set-up was exactly what I had been looking for. It took a year for the trio and other family and friends to get the bakery open.I remark on how busy Aran is, and am informed it does some  transactions a day . The elongated Scottish tourist season means they are busy all year round rather than the traditional Easter to September.ldquoPeople have no idea how much work goes into this and how much we bake every single day, she says. A production kitchen on a small industrial park up the road in Birnam has helped alleviate the flow.So far, so impressive.But Irsquom intrigued.Alongside gorgeous recipes on how to make the goodies in the bakery ndash think Whisky Eccles cakes, pistachio and lime loaf, or butternut squash and Birnam honey loafndash her new book features little drop-in biogs of her regular customers and staff, many of them men, and also of her father. So the female vibe of her previous book, in which she praised the influence of women on home cooking, seems to have morphed into something more collegiate and collaborative ndash as well as less sugary-sweet. Aran follows a day in the le of the bakery, hour by hour and ritual by ritual, and there are recipes for sandwiches, salads, savoury tarts and sandwiches ndash and a heavy emphasis on sourdough breads, brioches and croissants.So, does running a bakery span the genders  ldquoYeah, it used to be all women but the balance is more even now. In fact, I call my team lsquoThe Boysrsquo, she says. ldquoGatherings was more focused on home and family whereas this is much bigger and wider in scope and people. What wersquore doing here is definitely more collaborative. People of both genders bring in ideas and suggestions, either orally or from memory, and we try them out. Wersquore doing continual RD and things are developing organically. And in the village, the wider community spirit is strong.She makes a point of sourcing ingredients, including the all-important flour, from the community and from Scotland as much as possible. Salmon is from the Dunkeld Smoke House, honey from master beekeeper John Taylor, and fresh produce is from the organic Dunkeld and Birnam Community Growing, known as The Field, and from Blackhall Farm. Butter is from Grahamrsquos Dairies, although her Lescure patisserie butter ndash good for croissants and pastries due to its high fat content ndash is from France. With Brexit in mind, she is looking for alternative local sources to provide her with the  kilos she goes through every week.ldquoThe really important thing for us is to be sustainable, she says.Her message about eating sensibly is also strong, and she cites the Rome-based food writer Rachel Roddy and the Irish writer Diana Henry as her food heroes for their ldquosensible approach to healthy eating.In Aran, she writes: ldquoSugar gets a bad rep, as does gluten, sadly. But my principles remain the same throughout this bizarre time. Use proper and honest ingredients and think of food as a source of fuel and satisfaction, not as something to fear or discuss negatively.Kale, which she says, ldquogets all the attention by the clean-eaters, and I worry it will put people off it, features strongly in her salad section alongside squash, carrot tops, heirloom tomatoes and asparagus. Therersquos a foraged nettle and pea quiche in a nod to Scottish culinary history and nettle pudding, ldquothe oldest recorded pudding in the book, but unlikely to make a reappearance.Her misgivings echo those expressed in the  Gatherings, in which she lamented the number of people of her age-group that she knew to have eating disorders or troubled relationships with food, and how ldquoearth-shattering that could be.The equal balance between sweet and savoury in Aran is notable, and again echoes the authorrsquos desire to change perceptions that baking is all about sweetness and stodge.Does she think her peer-group ndash at almost  she is somewhere between a Millennial and the younger so-called Generation Z ndash are confused about food and diet  ldquoYes, she replies, without hesitation. ldquoI am from the generation with arguably the most delusional approach to food. Therersquos so much noise surrounding it on social media. The influencer set are hugely to blame when it comes to diet issues. People arenrsquot sure about where they stand as they receive mixed messages almost every day.With veganism gaining in popularity among Gen Zedders, does she offer vegan options  ldquoA couple, but thatrsquos not something we do massively, she replies, with an almost imperceptible sigh. ldquoApart from the fact that itrsquos very hard to cater for every possible dietary requirement, our ethos here is hugely based on local, as opposed to dietary.ldquoTherersquos quite a contentious discourse about veganism. I think itrsquos doing more damage to the planet than eating dairy from the farm  miles down the road."As well as her concerns about food miles, she also has health worries. ldquoI think itrsquos crazy to eliminate so many food groups at once, as veganism advocates. Itrsquos about cutting out a huge amount of the foods wersquove been eating for thousands of years. Problems seem to have occurred with the processed foods wersquove had available for the last  years. Tradition has never done us any harm. Now everyonersquos terried about their health.Sipping milky tea and casting an eye over the ever-forming queue at the counter, she continues: ldquoIt makes me laugh when people come in to our bakery looking for gluten-free. But you can eat our sourdough bread because itrsquos slow-fermented for  hours, which reduces the gluten content dramatically, is more easily digested and therefore better for your gut. I spend a lot of time trying to tell people to try sourdough because itrsquos the best thing you can possibly eat.ldquoI tell them thatthey buy a supermarket loaf they should toast it before eating it to finish off the baking. Itrsquos over-processed and over-yeasted to bake in minutes rather than days and contains  ingredients instead of just three or four. When you eat it itrsquos going to keep cooking in your stomach and make you feel heavy and bloated. Bread should never feel heavy.ldquoEverything processed is why wersquove lost touch with fresh food. E-numbers, additives, colourants, preservatives and so on are all man-made and, of course, theyrsquore going to cause damage and health problems. Naturally occurring ingredients are hardly to blame.Traditional Scottish iced gingerbread, almond and pistachio croissants and chocolate brownies are her biggest sellers. ldquoItrsquos OK to have sugar in moderation. Little and often, she says, smiling. Her own favourites are the sourdough sandwiches made fresh every day and filled with locally sourced greenery. ldquoWe donrsquot do them to order, otherwise wersquod be making cheese and ham every day, she says, grinning.She already has her eyes on the future, and hopes to open a village greengrocers soon. ldquoWe want to stay in Dunkeld and open a village store where things will be properly sourced and we can support the local area, she says. ldquoAt the moment we can only buy plastic-wrapped apples from Spain at the local Co-op. Wersquod like to further help the local growers and producers, while completing the circular system in terms of sustainability, cutting food waste and increasing food security.She concedes that shersquos in the privileged position of being in the main street of a historic village which is popular with tourists with no large supermarkets or fast-food chains to dilute her influence. The local independent butcher, smokehouse, deli and whisky shop are hardly going to do that. In fact, she believes she is part of wider grassroots movement in Scotland that is being fed ndash and in turn consumed ndash by social media.The downside of being part of the Gen Z zeitgeist is she has in the past fallen foul of social mediarsquos more unpleasant side. A self-taught cook who grew up in Dunkeld, Shedden suffered a Twitter backlash when, as a contestant on GBBO, she said shersquod forgotten to switch on the electric oven because her parents had an Aga at home that she had over  cookbooks, most of them French and that she had picked up a recipe for biscotti while travelling in Italy. Such comments resulted in the Twittersphere posting that she was ldquotoo posh, ldquotoo middle-class and ldquotoo professional ndash comments that were picked up by the tabloids.She says now: ldquoI havenrsquot been on Twitter for months. I love Instagram, itrsquos a great way to communicate and a huge part of our business comes through it. It also helped us market our Crowdfunding campaign. It is about sharing. It is far more my vibe and less threatening than Twitter.ldquoThrough Instagram it never fails to amaze me how many fantastic wee independent food places, producers and initiatives there are right across Scotland now, she adds. ldquoI think people are a lot more aware of what theyrsquore eating and where their food comes from. They are aware of sourcing and what theyrsquore putting in their systems. Theyrsquore more interested in that than in price. I like to think that from our tiny part of the planet wersquore changing things bit by bit.Aran, Recipes and Stories from a Bakery in the Heart of Scotland, by Flora Shedden, is published by Hardie Grant at pound.BUTTERNUT SQUASH AND BIRNAM HONEYWe do our absolute best to source as many local ingredients as possible, and always encourage customers to come through the door with any of their own goods. One day, we received a wonky squash from a local gardener and a couple of jars of Birnam honey from a lovely man called Mark, and we knew we had to combine them. This is a mash-up of the only three recipes I could find that contained more butternut squash than sugarand the end result is quite unique. Not dissimilar to a tea cake, the crumb is very soft, and perfect with a cup of Lady Grey tea.Makes xgloafor a xxcmloaf gbutternut squash, peeledand roughly chopped sunflower oil, for roasting gunsalted butter gsoft brown sugar grunny honey egg gself-raising flour ggroundalmonds  golive oil ggolden raisinszest of  orangefrac teaspoon mixed spiceDemerara sugar, for scatteringPreheat the oven to C . Grease and line a loaf tin.Tip the squash into a roasting tin and drizzle with a little oil, but with no seasoning, which will feel bizarreyour roast a lot of veg. Cook for  minutes or until soft and tender ndash it doesnrsquot need to be too well coloured. We tend to roast a big batch, remove the amount needed for this recipe once cooked, then season the rest and use in salads. Let the squash cool down before blitzing to form a smooth pureacutee.In the bowl of a free-standing mixer, beat the butter, sugar and honey until smooth and pale. Add the egg, flour, almonds,using, and oil. Beat again until fully combined. Add the cooled pureacutee, raisins, zest and spice and mix together by hand. Pour into the prepared tin, sprinkle generously with Demerara sugar and bake for ndash minutes, or until cooked through and a kne inserted into the middle comes out clean.

title: scottish-council-leader-apologises-ram-yer-union-yer-hoop-tweet
story: John Ross, head of South Lanarkshire council, also posted images of a union jack flying from a pile of dog faeces, captioned with: ldquothe perfect answer to our unionist friends.The Hamilton South councillor posted the message after attending Saturdayrsquos independence rally in Glasgow, however it has drawn widespread criticism from opponents.:Former Scottish Premiership keeper to stand for Conservatives in general electionLiberal Democrat group leader Robert Brown and Labour group leader Joe Fagan have both criticised the SNP council leader for the tweet.Cllr Brown said: ldquoI really donrsquot know what Councillor Ross is thinking of in pushing these childish and offensive tweets on social media.ldquoSadly it is not the first time we have had such stuff from the SNP leader of South Lanarkshire Council.ldquoUnpleasant comments like this show an arrogance and contempt for the views of other people we can do without ndash people are already bitterly ided by the independence issue and by Brexit without senior SNP representatives stoking the fires of resentment and prejudice.ldquoJohn Ross should recognise the council leader represents everyone and stop being a cheerleader for the more unpleasant parts of his nationalist cause.Cllr Ross tweeted from his personal account and did not tweet in connection with his role as leader of South Lanarkshire Council.He has since deleted the tweet and apologised for sending it in the first place.I deleted a retweet from Saturdayrsquos Indy rally because I accept thatoffended some, it was not language I would normally use. I make no opology for holding the view that the UK is in a mess  Scotland would be better out of the union but I do apologise for any offence causedHe said: ldquoI was one of the thousands of people who took part in last weekendrsquos independence rally. My support for independence is well known, having been a member of the SNP since , and I am proud to be part of the campaign for another independence referendum.Mr Ross later deleted the tweet, but users were quick to screenshot itldquoIt is very clear to me that the UK is presently in a mess and that Scotland would be better off out of the Union, and that was the essence of the messages on the posters that I tweeted from the rally.:Stormzy blasts Jacob Rees-Mogg over dumb Grenfell tragedy commentsldquoHowever, the wording and images were not the sort of thing I would use myself and when I had a chance to reflect on this, I decided to delete the tweet from my timeline.ldquoI respect that other people may not share my political views and will be careful to take cognisance of this in any future tweets.ldquoI am fully committed to doing the best that I can for South Lanarkshire and all its residents, regardless of their political views or none. Certainly, I never intended to offend and my apologies go to anyone who was offended.All councillors are subject to the Standardrsquos Commission for Scotlandrsquos code of conduct and receive social media advice as part of training based on the code.South Lanarkshire Council declined to comment.

title: labour-nicola-sturgeon-wasting-time-preparing-hold-balance-power
story: The shadow chancellor said Labour would not form any ldquopacts or coalitions with the SNPJeremy Corbyn fails to secure a majority.It came as the First Minister did not rule out entering into a DUP-style ldquoconfidence and supply arrangement with Labour in exchange for a second independence referendum.The DUP agreed to prop up Theresa Mayrsquos Government after the  election, by supporting the Conservative administration on key issues.Ms Sturgeon has repeatedly ruled out entering into any formal coalition with a minority Labour Government.But asked on Sky News whether she would ldquodo a deal like the DUP on a confidence and supply basis, she said: ldquoWell, letrsquos see what the arithmetic is ndash there will be no formal coalition.She added: ldquoWe will see what the circumstances are. What I was about to go on to say is that I would favour more, and I think be more likely to end up in, a situation where we have an issue by issue arrangement where we support on some things and donrsquot support on others.ldquoBut wersquoll drive a hard bargain and wersquoll stand up for Scotlandrsquos interests, and wersquoll stand up for the kind of progressive values that people across the UK think are important and wersquoll want to see a very strong position on Brexit.It emerged earlier this week that Ms Sturgeon is set to enter discussions with the UK civil service about her priorities in the event of any deal with Labour.These include a second independence referendum and the devolution of drug powers to Scotland.Whitehall officials can speak to opposition parties as part of a long-standing convention allowing them to prepare for a potential change in government.But last night, Mr McDonnell said: ldquoIf these reports are true then Nicola Sturgeon has been wasting her time. There will be no pacts or coalitions with the SNP.ldquoLabourrsquos plan for real change will give , Scots a pay rise and deliver around poundbn worth of investment that will transform Scotlandrsquos communities and public services.ldquoWe intend to win a majority butwe end up with a minority administration, we will put that policy programme to Parliament andthe SNP donrsquot support that then they will have to explain to the Scottish people why they rejected such a transformative agenda for Scotland.There has been widespread speculation that the SNP would agree to prop up a minority Labour Government in exchange for the power to hold a second independence referendum.Speaking to journalists while campaigning in Dalkeith, the First Minister also hit out at the SNPrsquos exclusion from General Election TV debates.Her party has complained to Sky News and Ofcom about the ldquodeeply undemocratic decision not to include it.Sky News proposed a live debate between Boris Johnson, Jeremy Corbyn and Jo Swinson, shortly after Ms Swinson said the Liberal Democrats would launch legal action against ITVit did not include her in its proposed head-to-head debate between the Tory and Labour leaders.The SNP said it has written to the head of Sky News calling for the party to be fully included in any debate, and making clear it could test the matter in the courtsit is not swtly resolved.Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoI think these are big issues.ldquoWe will continue to have fairly rigorous discussions with the broadcasters ndash both about the leadersrsquo debates, but also generally just about how the SNP is reflected in the overall coverage.ldquoWe could hold the balance of power after this election.Elsewhere, the First Minister insisted she is not concerned about alienating Brexit-supporting SNP voters by adopting a firmly pro-EU stance.Asked whether she feared the party would face a backlash, after earlier comments that % to % of SNP supporters also backed Brexit, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoNo I donrsquot - I donrsquot worry. In politics, you have to decide what side of issues yoursquore on - big defining issues.ldquoYou only have to look at Labour to see what happens to parties who try to straddle the fence and arenrsquot frank with people.ldquoBut however people voted on Brexit, I think people believe that itrsquos a mess and chaotic.ldquoMost people I speak to - including the minority in Scotland that voted to leave - actually just want to escape the whole sorry saga.ldquoSo Irsquom convinced that the right thing to do is be straight with people and honest with people about how we escape that and how we put our future in our hands so we donrsquot find ourselves in this kind of position again.

title: aldi to trial reusable fresh produce bags
story: The Ellon and Inverurie Aldi stores will trial reusable bags for loose fruit and vegetables in an effort to cut single-use plastics.From the end of November the stores will offer the bags as a more sustainable alternative to single-use plastic.The drawstring bags are made from recycled plastic bottles and will be sold for p each.This is the supermarket’s latest step to reduce unnecessary plastic as it works towards reducing plastic packaging by % by the end of .If introduced nationally, the initiative will remove the equivalent of  tonnes of single-use plastic from circulation each year.Fritz Walleczek, Managing Director of Corporate Responsibility at Aldi, said: “We are committed to cutting the amount of plastic that Aldi and our customers use, particularly excess or single-use plastic like produce bags.“We are hopeful that our customers across Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire will embrace these new reusable produce bags whenever they’re buying loose fruit and veg and, together, we will be able to take more than  tonnes of plastic a year out of circulation.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Drivers John Skinner, Ian Dixon and Ally Ferris promote free travel for all Veterans, Cadets and armed forces personnel for this years Remembrance Sunday events "  "  First Bus offers free journeys in honour of Remembrance Sunday viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"

title: birds put on a show at forvie reserve
story: Photographers have captured stunning images of wild geese and waders flocking to a local nature reserve.Images taken at Scottish Natural Heritagenational nature reserve at Forvie reveal the mass migration of wild birds from Iceland, Greenland and Svalbard.Stuart MacQuarrie, SNH’s Head of Nature Reserves, said: “To see a flock of geese as they lt off from their night-time roost is one of Scotland’s greatest wildle spectacles. It’s such a remarkable aerial display, made even better by the chorus of their high-pitched calls.“These amazing birds migrate as far as , miles to reach Scotland for their winter feeding, before ing to more northern climes in the spring. And there’s plenty of time for people to come out to one of our nature reserves over the next few months and see this marvellous display for themselves.” At Forvie, there are about  waders, including  dferent species, on the Ythan estuary over autumn. There are good numbers of redshanks, lapwings, curlews, dunlins, golden plovers and oyster catchers. An occasional rarity also shows up at Forvie, this year including a great egret, ten common cranes – and a terek sandpiper, only the second ever spotted in North East Scotland and the th in Scotland.The best places to watch them are from the hide at Waulkmill or the two laybys that overlook the estuary north of Newburgh on the A, where you can use your car as a hide and watch the undisturbed birds. There are also good views to be had by parking at theWaterside car parkand walking down the north side of the river on the Dune Trail.SNH’s Forvie reserve manage, David Pickett, explains:“These fantastic viewpoints make the Ythan one of the most accessible birdwatching spots in Scotland for waders.The best time to watch these amazing birds is approaching high tide, as the water is moving the birds closer to you.”For more info about Forvie nature reserve see:www.nnr-scotland.org.uk.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Engineers installing the two concrete shafts"  Progress at Kintore rail station site viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: expansion plans set to boost kintore businesses
story: Two Kintore-based businesses are set to more than double in size and create around  jobs with ambitious six-figure expansion plans.Husband and we team, James and Rebecca Carr, who run Kintore Car Sales and Rebecca Carr Hair Salon, are expanding both businesses to enhance their offering in the area.Mr Carr has moved his car sales and valeting firm to a two-acre site adjacent to his other facility which has quadrupled the size of his business footprint, allowing him to add a new servicing ision to the business.The move has already seen the headcount increase to five with plans to double staff numbers to support the continuing expansion of the seven-year-old business.Mrs Carr, who launched her salon in  which has  employees and more than , clients, is set to expand into a purpose-designed, sq ft building on the site of the previous car sales courtyard, in addition to continuing to operate her current salon in the village’s Midmill Parade.The new venture, Rebecca Carr Residence, will add a beauty lounge to the services, with the venue set to include private beauty rooms, in addition to pedicure stations, a nail and brow bar, make-up artist station and a retail gt section.The ‘Residence’ will also boast a café with outdoor space which will be run by fellow local business, From Bakery Lane, and will also boast private customer parking.The renovation, which is due to complete by November, will more than double the size of Mrs Carr’s business and create a further  jobs in the village.The couple, who also live in the village, are committed to investing in added in a repairs ision.”Mrs Carr, who won an emerging entrepreneur business award and a global hairdressing award last year, said: “I had initially planned to open additional salons but with  per title: first bus offers free journeys in honour of remembrance sunday
story: Bus operator First Bus is providing free travel to all armed forces personnel, veterans and cadets travelling to services and events across Scotland for Remembrance Sunday .All armed forces personnel, veterans and cadets showing their unorm and badges, or a recognised ID badge, can claim free travel up to pm on Sunday as they travel to and from Remembrance Day activities. The concession by one of Scotland’s biggest bus operator is in honour of all the fallen and the surviving veterans of conflict and it means that services across all three operating companies in First Aberdeen, First Glasgow and First Scotland East will be honouring the offer.Andrew Jarvis, Managing Director of First Scotland, said: “Remembrance Sunday is an important and solemn reminder of the sacrices made by so many in our Armed Forces and we wanted to do something to mark the occasion.“We have a number of veterans working for First Bus across all of our Scotland depots and we are very proud of their efforts and sacrice, so this is our way of saying thank you to them as well as honouring all men and women who choose to serve and protect the freedoms our country now takes for granted.“We hope this concession on our services will make it as easy as possible for as many Veterans, Armed Forces personnel and cadets to attend the ious Remembrance services and events up and down the country on Sunday to mark the occasion.”Gordon Michie, the head of fundraising at Poppyscotland, added: “Remembrance Sunday is an important moment in the national psyche. This is especially so for those who have selflessly served in our Armed Forces, many of whom have friends who have made the ultimate sacrice.“Providing free travel to veterans to help them attend Remembrance Sunday events across the country is a wonderful gesture by First Group and we commend them for this, and for their ongoing commitment to the Armed Forces community.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Bonfire Night is the busiest night of the year for the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service." story: Garioch Sports Centre in Inverurie has announced they are adding a Family Membership to their existing offering.The new membership will be available as a Black Friday deal throughout the month of November as part of Garioch Sports Centre’s ‘Black November’ initiative.The membership will launch on Friday, November  and will be available to purchase until Saturday, November .Kevin Bonarius, Chief Operating Officer, said: "Our Family Membership has been a long time coming.
